msDesc.p: Daily Journal for 1938, black leather binding with red leather spine. Pre-printed calendars appear on the inside front and back covers; pre-printed information also appears on 6 pages: calendar and publishing information on 2 preliminary pages; 2 pages advertising the company’s services in the last third of the notebook; and the 2 final pages printed with legal holidays and postage rates. The 183 pages dedicated to the calendar year are lined pages divided in half so that, except for the page for December 31, each leaf contains two dates. Following this are 7 pre-printed pages headed "Memoranda" and 24 pre-printed pages for bookkeeping: the first 12 of these, each headed with the month, is dedicated to cash received and paid; the second 12, each again headed with the month, are dedicated to “Bills Payable” and “Receivable.” First image with MM's writing is the inside front cover. RML number written in pencil: 1250/7.

Burns In a letter to Thomson, Sept. 1793,: I do not know the air;
and until I am complete master of a tune, in my own singing (such as
it is), I never can compose for it. My way is: I consider the
poetic sentiment correspondent to my idea of the musical expression;
then choose my theme; begin one stanza; when that is composed,
which is generally the most difficult part of
the business, I walk out, sit down now & then, look out for
subjects in nature around me that are in unison and harmony
with the cogitations of my fancy, & workings of my bosom,
humming every now and then the air with the verses I have
framed. When I feel my muse beginning to jade, I retire
to the solitary fireside of my study, & then commit my effusion
to paper; swinging at intervals on the hind-legs of my elbow-chair,
by way of calling forth my own critical strictures as my
pen goes on. Seriously, this at home is almost invariably my way.’

1 About fifteen [i.e. 1703 or thereabouts], I got acquainted

2 Aristotle had considered poetry as an imitation. But the poet,
he had counselled, must not simply copy what he finds before
him. His art must help nature to realize the perfection, the
grand simplicity, which she is aiming at but is always being
accidentally prevented from realizing. The poet must discover
the balked intentions of nature and so vicariously
free her. He must allow nature freedom to become Nature.
. . . . He will do this by . . . seeking the common ground in
the mind of all men . . . and by erecting his poem on that.
First follow Nature, & your judgment frame
By her just standard, which is still the same:

lg.l: “Those who are conversant w. the Writings of the Antients, will
observe a great difference between what they and the Moderns
have publish’d upon this Subject [love]. The occasions
upon which the Poems of the former are written, are such as happen
to every mMan almost that is in Love; and the Thoughts
such, as are natural for every Man in love to think. The
Moderns on the other hand have sought out for Occasions
that none meet with, but themselves; and fill their
Verses with thoughts that are surprizing & glittering, but not
tender, passionate or natural to a mMan in Love.
